[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the robot is holding a human wrist. The wrist appears slightly bent out of shape at the joint. The goal is to gently maneuver the wrist back into its proper alignment.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The axes represent the frame of reference relative to the robot's wrist.
The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion up and down relative to the tabletop in the image. Positive Z corresponds to upwards motion, and negative Z corresponds to downwards motion.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move slightly downwards to properly align the bones of the wrist joint, since the wrist appears dislocated in the upward direction.
The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion to the right and left relative to the tabletop in the image. Positive X corresponds to rightward motion, and negative X corresponds to leftward motion.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move slightly to the left, as the dislocation could involve a lateral misalignment that needs correction.
The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion into and out of the image, forward and backward relative to the robot. Positive Y corresponds to motion away from the robot, and negative Y corresponds to motion towards the robot.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move slightly forward, as the dislocation could involve a slight displacement in that direction.
To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved downwards, slightly left, and slightly forward, along with small corrective rotations to help the bones realign.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: Think very carefully about the estimated mass, material, stiffness, friction coefficient of the object based off the visual information and semantic knowledge about the object. If object is articulated, do the same reasoning for whatever joint / degree of freedom enables motion.
- Environmental Factors: Think very carefully about the various environmental factors in task like gravity, surface friction, damping, hinge resistance that would interact with the object over the course of the task.
- The relevant object is a human arm and wrist. The human arm is composed of bone, muscle and skin. It has mass 2 kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.6.
- The surface of interaction is the robot gripper and the human wrist. The gripper surface has a static friction coefficient of 0.6 with the object.
- Contact Types: Maintaining a pinch grasp is important, as is applying some pressure to the wrist bones to facilitate the re-alignment. Edge contact may also be involved as the bones slide against each other.
- Motion Type: The motion involves gentle pushing and sliding to encourage the wrist bones back into the correct position.
- Contact Considerations: Additional force may be needed along the grasp axis to keep the gripper firmly in place.
- Motion along axes: the robot exerts motion in a “linear,” “rotational,” “some combination” fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes.
- Task duration: the task motion, forces, and other properties will last for approximately 5 seconds.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: mass of the wrist, friction coefficient between skin and gripper.
- Relevant equations: F = ma, static friction force = mu * normal force.
- Relevant assumptions: The mass of the wrist is relatively small compared to the arm. The primary resistance to motion comes from friction and the internal resistance of the misaligned joint.
- Computations: Assume the force required for each axis is calculated independently for simplicity.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 2 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface: The small motions will overcome static friction and gently guide the wrist back in place.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the gentle motion along the X-axis to correct the lateral misalignment, the object in the image must exert negative force along the X-axis with magnitude 1 N.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to gently shift the wrist forward for realignment, the object in the image must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 1 N.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon the slight downward adjustment needed to align the bones, the object in the image must exert negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude 1 N.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon subtle rotations may be necessary to guide the bones, the object in the image must exert angular clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0.1 N-m.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon subtle rotations may be necessary to guide the bones, the object in the image must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0.1 N-m.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon only small corrections should be necessary to avoid excessive strain, the object in the image must exert no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Grasping force: a firm grasp is needed to maintain control of the wrist during manipulation, while not applying undue pressure. Thus, 10 to 20 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human wrist, mass approximately 2 kg, skin and bone material, static friction coefficient with gripper approximately 0.6."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Move downwards, slightly left, and slightly forward, with slight corrective rotations, to realign the wrist joint."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [-0.005, 0.005, -0.005]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [-1, 1, -1, -0.1, 0.1, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 15
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 5
```

[end of motion plan]

Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
